answers.body: You need to provide (1) relevant table definitions (2) relevant view definitions (3) sample table data and (4) sample result data. Without all of that your question is just a guessing game. It also probably belongs on dba.stackexchange.com rather than here.

My goal is to load transactions for only those customers which is present in Input View and do some processing on them later.

The current implementation is:

1. Hdfs has data for customers with columns (cust_id, date, uuid)
So , first I read this data and create input view on this one.

2. Now later in the pipeline I have create a view from transactions table of DB having schema
(transaction_id, customer_id, date, transaction_amt, tran_type, current_amt).

3. At this point I now have both views with me input and transactions view. Then i am running SPARK SQL on them as "Select i.cust_id, t.transaction_id, t.transaction_amt, t.tran_type from transactions t join input i on i.cust_id=t.customer_id && i.date= t.date"

Now what happens here is that Spark will load all the data from transactions table to create view which is not efficient.
I want to achieve some filter push down in RDBMS also like Spark does for Hdfs.

'Spark will load all the data from transactions table to create view': no it won't. Creating the view just registers the SQL that defines it. No data is loaded at all. When you SELECT from that view, the data required to fill it is loaded, but that won't be the entirety of any table provided you have suitable indexes matching your WHERE and JOIN ... USING or ON clauses. A Data Engineer you should already know all this.

items.title: Pushing down filters in RDBMS with Java Spark
items.body:
I have been working as a Data Engineer and got this issue.
I came across a use case where I have a view(lets name it as inputView) which is created by reading data from some source.
Now somewhere later in the pipeline I have to again read data from RDBMS ,create a view(transactions).
Then I am running a Spark SQL query to join transactions view with input View based on some column.

Problem:
The problem here is that only the data which is required from transactions should be loaded but whole data is getting read.

Proposed Solution(Not Sure it is safe)
To solve this issue we are planning to create temp table in db and store inputView in RDBMS then do a join at db level and get data.
But the issue seems with this approach that
1. Temp data is available per session only. Spark executors will have their separate session while inserting inputView data in db. So how are they going to read data after join as spark write api will create session write data and then closes session. Even before the join query the data will be gone.
2. If I write each record one by one from driver using JDBC prepareStatements. Then for doing join and reading data I have to use the same connection to read data, I can't use spark read api to read it. So I read data by JDBC only, which will eventually load all the data in the driver, that can cause OOM.
3. Suppose multiple pipelines are running and mulitple pipelines try to insert their inputView data in some temp table. The database will be getting a lot of load, Won't it crash ?

Any Suggestion/Solution is welcomed.

Thanks in advance.

answers.body:
You need to use imageLoader with svg decoder factory. Thanks to tyg for pointing out I don't need the file.

Here's a short code to handle that. Hope it helps:

class MainActivity : ComponentActivity() {
    override fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) {
        super.onCreate(savedInstanceState)
        val svgContent = """
    <svg width="100" height="100" viewBox="0 0 100 100">
        <circle cx="50" cy="50" r="40" stroke="black" stroke-width="3" fill="red" />
    </svg>
""".trimIndent() //You can paste your svg here
        enableEdgeToEdge()
        setContent {
            ComposeGlowTheme {
                Column(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(), horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally) {
                    Text("SVG Display", modifier = Modifier.padding(16.dp))
                    val imageLoader = ImageLoader.Builder(this@MainActivity)
                        .components {
                            add(SvgDecoder.Factory())
                        }
                        .build()
                    AsyncImage(
                        model = svgContent.toByteArray(),
                        imageLoader = imageLoader,
                        contentDescription = "Local SVG Test",
                        modifier = Modifier.size(200.dp)
                    )
                }

            }
        }
    }
}

You can simply pass the SVG data as a ByteArray:

AsyncImage(
    model = svgData.toByteArray(),
    contentDescription = null,
)

I'm not sure if it works in a Compose Preview; it will work running on a device, though.

items.title: How to load SVG content images(not url) using Coil on Android

answers.body:
You need to use a Loader instead of the navigateToURL function. You can create a Main movie to load each external swf and add in the main stage when the download complete.

Use the following code to automate the process:

import flash.display.Loader;
import flash.events.Event;
import flash.events.MouseEvent;

// Vars
var currentMovieIndex:uint = 0;
var currentMovie:Loader;
// Put your movies here
var swfList:Array = ["swf1.swf", "swf2.swf", "swf3.swf"];

// Add the event listener to the next and previous button
previousButton.addEventListener(MouseEvent.CLICK, loadPrevious);
nextButton.addEventListener(MouseEvent.CLICK, loadNext);


// Loads a swf at secified index
function loadMovieAtIndex (index:uint) {

    // Unloads the current movie if exist
    if (currentMovie) {
        removeChild(currentMovie);
        currentMovie.unloadAndStop();
    }

    // Updates the index
    currentMovieIndex = index;

    // Creates the new loader
    var loader:Loader = new Loader();
    // Loads the external swf file
    loader.load(new URLRequest(swfList[currentMovieIndex]));

    // Save he movie reference 
    currentMovie = loader;

    // Add on the stage
    addChild(currentMovie);
}

// Handles the previous button click
function loadPrevious (event:MouseEvent) {
    if (currentMovieIndex) { // Fix the limit
        currentMovieIndex--; // Decrement by 1
        loadMovieAtIndex(currentMovieIndex);
    }
}

// Handles the next button click
function loadNext (event:MouseEvent) {
    if (currentMovieIndex < swfList.length-1) { // Fix the limit
        currentMovieIndex++; // Increment by 1
        loadMovieAtIndex(currentMovieIndex);
    }
}

// Load the movie at index 0 by default
loadMovieAtIndex(currentMovieIndex);

Dowload the demo files here: http://cl.ly/Lxj3

package {

import flash.display.Sprite;

import flash.display.Shape;

import flash.text.TextField;

import flash.text.TextFormat;

import flash.text.TextFieldAutoSize;

import flash.events.MouseEvent;

import flash.external.ExternalInterface;

import flash.system.fscommand;

import flash.utils.getQualifiedClassName;

public class Buttons extends Sprite {

    // konfigurasi tombol

    private const BTN_WIDTH:Number = 120;

    private const BTN_HEIGHT:Number = 36;

    private const GAP:Number = 12;

    public function Buttons() {

        // panggil inisialisasi

        init();

    }

    private function init():void {

        // buat tombol Back, Next, Materi, Home, Close

        var backBtn:Sprite = createButton("Back");

        backBtn.x = 20;

        backBtn.y = 20;

        addChild(backBtn);

        backBtn.addEventListener(MouseEvent.CLICK, onBack);

        var nextBtn:Sprite = createButton("Next");

        nextBtn.x = backBtn.x + BTN_WIDTH + GAP;

        nextBtn.y = backBtn.y;

        addChild(nextBtn);

        nextBtn.addEventListener(MouseEvent.CLICK, onNext);

        var materiBtn:Sprite = createButton("Materi");

        materiBtn.x = nextBtn.x + BTN_WIDTH + GAP;

        materiBtn.y = backBtn.y;

        addChild(materiBtn);

        materiBtn.addEventListener(MouseEvent.CLICK, onMateri);

        var homeBtn:Sprite = createButton("Home");

        homeBtn.x = materiBtn.x + BTN_WIDTH + GAP;

        homeBtn.y = backBtn.y;

        addChild(homeBtn);

        homeBtn.addEventListener(MouseEvent.CLICK, onHome);

        var closeBtn:Sprite = createButton("Close");

        closeBtn.x = homeBtn.x + BTN_WIDTH + GAP;

        closeBtn.y = backBtn.y;

        addChild(closeBtn);

        closeBtn.addEventListener(MouseEvent.CLICK, onClose);

        // set cursor pointer

        setButtonModeRecursive(this);

    }

    // fungsi pembuat tombol sederhana

    private function createButton(labelText:String):Sprite {

        var s:Sprite = new Sprite();

        // background rectangle

        var bg:Shape = new Shape();

        bg.graphics.lineStyle(1, 0x333333);

        bg.graphics.beginFill(0xEEEEEE);

        bg.graphics.drawRoundRect(0, 0, BTN_WIDTH, BTN_HEIGHT, 8, 8);

        bg.graphics.endFill();

        s.addChild(bg);

        // teks

        var tf:TextField = new TextField();

        tf.selectable = false;

        tf.autoSize = TextFieldAutoSize.LEFT;

        tf.text = labelText;

        var fmt:TextFormat = new TextFormat();

        fmt.font = "\_sans";

        fmt.size = 14;

        fmt.align = "center";

        tf.setTextFormat(fmt);

        // center text horizontally & vertically

        tf.x = (BTN_WIDTH - tf.textWidth) / 2 - 2;

        tf.y = (BTN_HEIGHT - tf.textHeight) / 2 - 2;

        s.addChild(tf);

        // hit area to ensure entire rect clickable

        var hit:Shape = new Shape();

        hit.graphics.beginFill(0, 0);

        hit.graphics.drawRoundRect(0, 0, BTN_WIDTH, BTN_HEIGHT, 8, 8);

        hit.graphics.endFill();

        s.addChild(hit);

        s.buttonMode = true;

        s.mouseChildren = false;

        // hover effect

        s.addEventListener(MouseEvent.MOUSE_OVER, function(e:MouseEvent):void {

            bg.alpha = 0.85;

        });

        s.addEventListener(MouseEvent.MOUSE_OUT, function(e:MouseEvent):void {

            bg.alpha = 1.0;

        });

        return s;

    }

    private function setButtonModeRecursive(container:Sprite):void {

        for (var i:int = 0; i \< container.numChildren; i++) {

            var child:\* = container.getChildAt(i);

            try {

                if (child is Sprite) {

                    child.buttonMode = true;

                }

            } catch (err:Error) {}

        }

    }

    // --- event handlers ---

    private function onBack(e:MouseEvent):void {

        // contoh: pindah ke frame sebelumnya jika project berbasis timeline

        try {

            if (stage && root && root is Sprite) {

                Sprite(root).gotoAndStop(Math.max(1, Sprite(root).currentFrame - 1));

            }

        } catch (err:Error) {

            // jika tidak ada timeline, panggil ExternalInterface

            try { ExternalInterface.call("console.log", "Back clicked"); } catch(err2:Error){}

        }

    }

    private function onNext(e:MouseEvent):void {

        try {

            if (stage && root && root is Sprite) {

                var nextFrame:int = Math.min(Sprite(root).totalFrames, Sprite(root).currentFrame + 1);

                Sprite(root).gotoAndStop(nextFrame);

            }

        } catch (err:Error) {

            try { ExternalInterface.call("console.log", "Next clicked"); } catch(err2:Error){}

        }

    }

    private function onMateri(e:MouseEvent):void {

        // contoh panggil fungsi menampilkan materi; ganti sesuai kebutuhan

        showMateri();

    }

    private function onHome(e:MouseEvent):void {

        // buka URL home (contoh: index.html) jika dijalankan di browser

        try {

            if (ExternalInterface.available) {

                ExternalInterface.call("function(){ window.location.href = window.location.origin + '/'; }");

            } else {

                // fallback: log

                trace("Home clicked");

            }

        } catch (err:Error) {

            trace("Home error: " + err.message);

        }

    }

    private function onClose(e:MouseEvent):void {

        // tutup aplikasi / window

        try {

            if (ExternalInterface.available) {

                ExternalInterface.call("function(){ window.close(); }");

            }

        } catch(err:Error) {}

        // fscommand("quit") akan bekerja pada projector / standalone player

        try {

            fscommand("quit");

        } catch (err:Error) {

            trace("Close called");

        }

    }

    // fungsi contoh yang dipanggil tombol Materi

    private function showMateri():void {

        // ganti sesuai kebutuhan: bisa memanggil frame "materi", membuka popup, atau menampilkan text

        trace("Menampilkan materi...");

        // contoh: jika timeline memiliki label "materi", pindah ke sana

        try {

            Sprite(root).gotoAndStop("materi");

        } catch (err:Error) {

            // jika tidak tersedia, tampilkan alert via ExternalInterface

            try {

                if (ExternalInterface.available) ExternalInterface.call("alert", "Materi: (Edit fungsi showMateri() di AS3 untuk menyesuaikan konten)");

            } catch (e:Error){}

        }

    }

}

}

items.title: How to Build a Generalised PHI Redaction System for Scanned and Selectable PDFs Using OCR + NLP Across Multiple Layouts?
items.body:
I am implementing a PHI redaction pipeline in Python and need a solution that reliably handles a wide range of PDF types:
• Scanned PDFs (image-only)
• Selectable text PDFs
• Mixed-content PDFs
• Multi-column medical reports
• Forms, tables, and irregular document structures

The objective is to detect and redact PHI elements (names, MRNs, DOB, phone numbers, addresses, etc.) in a consistent manner.

Tools Tried

I have experimented with:
• OCR: Tesseract, PaddleOCR
• PDF libraries: PyMuPDF, pdfplumber
• NLP: spaCy NER, regex-based detection
However, results vary significantly between documents due to layout differences, inconsistent OCR quality, rotated text, tables, headers/footers, and differing visual structures.

Challenges
• OCR output layout is inconsistent across pages
• PHI appears in multiple regions (headers, footers, tables, inline text)
• Multi-column text is merged incorrectly
• Difficult to build a single workflow that handles all PDF structures
• Need deterministic output for compliance

What I Need Help With

I am looking for technical recommendations on:
1. An end-to-end architecture for robust PHI extraction across diverse PDF layouts.
2. OCR best practices to improve accuracy across noisy documents.
3. Handling multi-column or irregular layouts before performing NER.
4. Combining OCR + layout models (e.g., LayoutLM, Donut, TrOCR) for better structural parsing.
5. Post-processing strategies to make PHI detection deterministic and auditable.
6. Example pipelines or libraries that support reliable redaction (masking, overlaying, or rewriting).

Any workflow suggestions, code patterns, or library recommendations would be very helpful.

answers.body:
On the surface, I don't see any technical difference.

But in terms of readability, data-testid may notice other developers that this is used for test case specifically, while id is may be in terms of styling.

Also id or class selectors can be changed more often if implementation changes.

Reference:

Making your UI tests resilient to change

There are at least two reasons to separate the testing ids and the regular ones. You will not feel a difference if these are not of concern to you (and the people who will use and maintain the system).

  1. Components reuse

React Components reuse is one of the core concepts of the framework. And in general, components can appear several times in one page/view. This easily leads to an id duplication, which in turn has the potential to break the logic of further processing of the page. Nobody loves duplicated ids.

  1. Cleaning the code for production

It's straightforward to employ any method of getting rid of data-testid attribute before publishing your package. But it's hard to be sure you would not clear anything other developers rely on when you keep your testing ids in the regular id field.

Existing answers could be more explicit about a crucial difference, which is that id is unique per page, while there's no such constraint on data-testid. Libraries like React Testing library and Playwright have explicit queries for one versus many test ids, e.g. getByTestId (an explicit assertion of one) and getAllByTestId.

The main issue with overloading the id attribute is that it's primarily used for application logic: targeting/identifying/selecting elements in HTML and JS and styling in CSS. data-testid is purely for testing and should have zero conflicts with page logic.

If you always use id, a reader of the code will have no idea whether that id is was added purely for testing selection, or if it's also used in application logic, or both. If used for both, something will break sooner or later.

On the other hand, the full decoupling of test ids from application logic lowers confidence in your tests, since the selection methods may reach elements users can't, or otherwise may not be reflective of reality.

The optimal approach is to use neither id or data-testid, preferring user-first accessible selection, which relies on implicit attributes tied to behavior and presentation.

items.title: Is there a way to target a pseudo-element in CSS by its class?

audio::-webkit-media-controls-play-button.pause {

u are using .weight(1f, fill = false)
but Correct Approach Modifier.weight(1f, fill = true)

Working Code

@OptIn(ExperimentalMaterial3Api::class)
@Composable
fun BottomSheetExample() {

    var showSheet by remember { mutableStateOf(false) }
    val sheetState = rememberModalBottomSheetState(skipPartiallyExpanded = false)
    val scope = rememberCoroutineScope()

    if (showSheet) {
        ModalBottomSheet(
            sheetState = sheetState,
            onDismissRequest = { showSheet = false }
        ) {

            Column(
                modifier = Modifier
                    .fillMaxWidth()
                    .navigationBarsPadding()   // ← Optional for spacing
                    .padding(16.dp)
            ) {

                // Scrollable content
                Column(
                    modifier = Modifier
                        .weight(1f, fill = true)   // ← Important!
                        .verticalScroll(rememberScrollState())
                ) {
                    repeat(30) {
                        Text(
                            text = "Item ${it + 1}",
                            style = MaterialTheme.typography.bodyLarge,
                            modifier = Modifier
                                .padding(vertical = 8.dp)
                                .fillMaxWidth()
                        )
                    }
                }

                // Fixed bottom button
                Button(
                    modifier = Modifier
                        .fillMaxWidth()
                        .padding(top = 16.dp),
                    onClick = {
                        scope.launch { sheetState.hide() }.invokeOnCompletion {
                            if (!sheetState.isVisible) showSheet = false
                        }
                    }
                ) {
                    Text("Click to Hide")
                }
            }
        }
    }

    // Button to open the sheet
    Box(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
    ) {
        Button(onClick = { showSheet = true }) {
            Text("Show Bottom Sheet")
        }
    }
}

If you want that behavior, you'd have to control the size of the column yourself during half-expanded state. Here I just took your code and edited a few bits.

@OptIn(ExperimentalMaterial3Api::class)
@Composable
fun Greeting() {
    // State to control the visibility of the bottom sheet
    var showBottomSheet by remember { mutableStateOf(false) }

    // State for the ModalBottomSheet itself
    val sheetState = rememberModalBottomSheetState(skipPartiallyExpanded = false)
    val scope = rememberCoroutineScope()

    Box(
        modifier = Modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
    ) {
        Button(onClick = { showBottomSheet = true }) {
            Text("Show Bottom Sheet")
        }
    }

    if (showBottomSheet) {
        ModalBottomSheet(
            onDismissRequest = { showBottomSheet = false },
            sheetState = sheetState
        ) {

            Column(
                modifier = Modifier
                    .fillMaxHeight()
                    .padding(16.dp),
                horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally
            ) {
                Column(
                    modifier = if (sheetState.currentValue == SheetValue.PartiallyExpanded) Modifier
                        .fillMaxHeight(0.4f)
                        .weight(1f, fill = false)
                        .verticalScroll(rememberScrollState()) else
                        Modifier
                            .weight(1f, fill = false)
                            .verticalScroll(rememberScrollState())  //Added part here
                ) {
                    for (i in 1..30) {
                        Text(
                            modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),
                            text = "Item $i",
                            style = MaterialTheme.typography.headlineMedium
                        )
                    }
                }
                Button(
                    modifier = Modifier.padding(top = 16.dp, bottom = 24.dp), //Put the if else in this bottom padding as well as it might have inconsistent behavior in half expanded and full expanded
                    onClick = {
                        scope.launch { sheetState.hide() }.invokeOnCompletion {
                            if (!sheetState.isVisible) {
                                showBottomSheet = false
                            }
                        }
                    }
                ) {
                    Text("Click to Hide")
                }
            }

        }
    }
}

Explanation: The halfexpanded state is a minor preview of the whole bottom sheet, so it displays the top part of the fully expanded content. The drawing of components happen on the whole bottom sheet even in halfexpanded state. That's why the weight doesn't work as we'd think, but it's working as it's supposed to. Your approach of fill = false is valid, it is needed in this code as well.

I hope this answers your question.

items.title: Make a Button always visible at the bottom of a Jetpack Compose ModalBottomSheet
items.body:
I am trying to implement a ModalBottomSheet in Jetpack Compose - Android where a "Click to Hide" button is always visible at the bottom of the sheet. This button should remain visible and pinned at the bottom regardless of whether the sheet is partially expanded or fully expanded. The content above the button should be scrollable if it exceeds the available space.

What I Want To Achieve:

  1. A ModalBottomSheet that supports both partially and fully expanded states.
  2. A scrollable list of items inside the sheet.
  3. A Button that is always visible at the bottom of the sheet. (PartiallyExpanded and Expanded)
@OptIn(ExperimentalMaterial3Api::class)
@Composable
fun Greeting(name: String, modifier: Modifier = Modifier) {
    // State to control the visibility of the bottom sheet
    var showBottomSheet by remember { mutableStateOf(false) }

    // State for the ModalBottomSheet itself
    val sheetState = rememberModalBottomSheetState(skipPartiallyExpanded = false)
    val scope = rememberCoroutineScope()

    Box(
        modifier = modifier.fillMaxSize(),
        contentAlignment = Alignment.Center
    ) {
        Button(onClick = { showBottomSheet = true }) {
            Text("Show Bottom Sheet")
        }
    }

    if (showBottomSheet) {
        ModalBottomSheet(
            onDismissRequest = { showBottomSheet = false },
            sheetState = sheetState
        ) {
            // Content of the bottom sheet
            Column(
                modifier = Modifier
                    .fillMaxHeight()
                    .padding(16.dp),
                horizontalAlignment = Alignment.CenterHorizontally
            ) {
                Column (modifier = Modifier
                    .weight(1f, fill = false)
                    .verticalScroll(rememberScrollState())){
                    for (i in 1..30) {
                        Text(modifier = Modifier.fillMaxWidth(),text = "Item $i", style = MaterialTheme.typography.headlineMedium)
                    }
                }
                Button(
                    modifier = Modifier.padding(top = 16.dp),
                    onClick = {
                        scope.launch { sheetState.hide() }.invokeOnCompletion {
                            if (!sheetState.isVisible) {
                                showBottomSheet = false
                            }
                        }
                    }
                ) {
                    Text("Click to Hide")
                }
            }

        }
    }
}

My current implementation with Modifier.fillMaxHeight() and Modifier.weight(1f) doesn't seem to work correctly in the partially expanded state. The button is not visible until I scroll to the very bottom of the content.

How can I modify my layout so the button is always visible at the bottom of the ModalBottomSheet's frame, both in the PartiallyExpanded and Expanded states?

items.title: How to optimize NetCDF files and dask for processing long-term climataological indices with xclim (ex. SPI using 30-day rolling window)?
items.body:
I am trying to analyze the 30 day standardized precipitation index for a multi-state range of the southeastern US for the year 2016. I'm using xclim to process a direct pull of gridded daily precipitation data from nClimGrid-Daily, which involves pulling about 40 years of data and doing a 30-day rolling mean of the daily sum precip. Resolution is daily and 48.3 km. What I was expected was the code to provide me the 30-day SPI for the entire range which I could then subset for the year 2016. Instead, I will run this on my HPC via ssh and then get kicked off the compute node halfway. I can run it on my local machine, but gets too hot to complete.

I downloaded the range I needed (8.8gb). After geographically and temporally subsetting, it's around 7gb. I can lazy load everything, but when I persist/compute with dask it just keeps stalling after running for a certain amount of time - a lot of processing power is going towards rechunking by xclim even though I've tried rechunking prior to avoid it. As a note, when I choose a coarses spatial resolution (county vs gridded) I can run this in less than an hour. With gridded, it breaks after about 3 hours. Please let me know if you have any suggestions!

import xarray as xr
from dask.distributed import Client, LocalCluster
import os
from pathlib import Path
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor, as_completed
import requests

#### bulk download files 
base_url = "https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/data/nclimgrid-daily/access/grids"
years = range(1976, 2017)
months = range(1, 13)

out_dir = Path("./nclimgrid_prcp")  # adjust as needed
out_dir.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)

max_workers = 16
timeout = 60  # seconds

def dl(year, month):
    fname = f"ncdd-{year}{month:02}-grd-scaled.nc"
    url = f"{base_url}/{year}/{fname}"
    path = out_dir / fname

    if path.exists():
        return path, "exists"

    try:
        r = requests.get(url, timeout=timeout, stream=True)
        r.raise_for_status()
        with open(path, "wb") as f:
            for chunk in r.iter_content(chunk_size=2**20):
                if chunk:
                    f.write(chunk)
        return path, "downloaded"
    except Exception as e:
        return path, f"error: {e}"


futures = []
with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=max_workers) as ex:
    for y in years:
        for m in months:
            futures.append(ex.submit(dl, y, m))

files = []
for fut in as_completed(futures):
    p, status = fut.result()
    print(p.name, status)
    if status in ("exists", "downloaded"):
        files.append(str(p))

####### End download files

files = sorted(glob.glob('nclimgrid_prcp/*.nc')) #access local files

def subset(ds):
    return ds.sel(
         lat=slice(30, 38),    
         lon=slice(-92, -78), 
    )
ds = xr.open_mfdataset(files, combine="by_coords"  preprocess=subset,engine='netcdf4')

pr = ds['prcp']
pr = pr.assign_attrs(units="mm/day")

pr = pr.chunk(
    {
        "time": -1,   
        "lat": 64,    
        "lon": 84,    
    }
)

cluster = LocalCluster()
client = Client(cluster)
client.cluster.scale(10)  

spi_30 = xc.indices.standardized_precipitation_index(
    pr,
    freq="D",   
    window=30)

You forgot to copy the prisma directory, since generating the Prisma Client requires the schema.prisma file. You should copy the whole prisma directory in case you also need the migrations.

Your final Dockerfile should contain the following:

WORKDIR /app
COPY package*.json .
COPY prisma ./prisma/ 
RUN npm install --only=prod

Here is another way to solve this.

Since the .prisma folder is needed by the prisma client as shown in the picture below or in the docs another way is to make sure it ships with your code. You can do this as follows.

Wrong way: ship the generated folder

You would think you can just include the generated files in the image by adding an exception rule for the .prisma folder to your .dockerignore (notice the exclamation point)

node_modules/
!nodes_modules/.prisma

But the query engine used by prisma is different for each operating system so you could run into troubles.

Correct way : generate the files with the image

Just add RUN npx prisma generate to your Dockerfile before the build command. This way the files are generated during the image creation and you don't have to run the prisma generate command on every container. The downside of this method is that your docker image will be larger. If this is an issue you can try with the other answers.

This error happens because docker doesn't install devDependencies, which means that it doesn't pick up the Prisma CLI.

To remedy this you can add the prisma CLI package to your dependencies instead of the devDependencies. (Making sure to run npm install afterward to update the package-lock.json)

I recently faced an issue with Prisma in Node.js where the client wouldn’t initialize:

Error: @prisma/client did not initialize yet. Please run "prisma generate" and try to import it again.

I know this has been solved, but I’m publishing my answer so others won’t have to suffer like I did.

Solutions

  1. Update your schema.prisma generator section to use the default provider:

    generator client {
  provider = "prisma-client-js"
}

  2. Regenerate Prisma Client after any schema changes:

    npx prisma generate

  3. Import and initialize Prisma Client in your Node.js code:

    import { PrismaClient } from "@prisma/client";

    const prisma = new PrismaClient();

    💡 Why this works

    • Using provider = "prisma-client-js" generates the client in the default node_modules/@prisma/client path.

    • Importing from @prisma/client ensures Node.js can find the generated client.

    • Regenerating after schema changes keeps the client in sync with your database models.

You can use this method to convert you currency in words:

function convertToWords(input) {

  var a, b, c, d, e, output, outputA, outputB, outputC, outputD, outputE;

  var ones = ['', 'one', 'two', 'three', 'four', 'five', 'six', 'seven', 'eight', 'nine'];

  if (input === 0) { // Zero

    output = "Rupees zero";

  } else if (input == 1) { // One

    output = "Rupee one only";

  } else { // More than one

    // Tens
    a = input % 100;
    outputA = oneToHundred_(a);

    // Hundreds
    b = Math.floor((input % 1000) / 100);
    if (b > 0 && b < 10) {
      outputB = ones[b];
    }

    // Thousands
    c = (Math.floor(input / 1000)) % 100;
    outputC = oneToHundred_(c);

    // Lakh
    d = (Math.floor(input / 100000)) % 100;
    outputD = oneToHundred_(d);

    // Crore
    e = (Math.floor(input / 10000000)) % 100;
    outputE = oneToHundred_(e);

    // Make string
    output = "Rupees";

    if (e > 0) {
      output = output + " " + outputE + " crore";
    }

    if (d > 0) {
      output = output + " " + outputD + " lakh";
    }

    if (c > 0) {
      output = output + " " + outputC + " thousand";
    }

    if (b > 0) {
      output = output + " " + outputB + " hundred";
    }

    if (input > 100 && a > 0) {
      output = output + " and";
    }

    if (a > 0) {
      output = output + " " + outputA;
    }

    output = output + " only";
  }

  return output;

}

function oneToHundred_(num) {

  var outNum;

  var ones = ['', 'one', 'two', 'three', 'four', 'five', 'six', 'seven', 'eight', 'nine'];

  var teens = ['ten', 'eleven', 'twelve', 'thirteen', 'fourteen', 'fifteen', 'sixteen', 'seventeen', 'eighteen', 'nineteen'];

  var tens = ['', '', 'twenty', 'thirty', 'forty', 'fifty', 'sixty', 'seventy', 'eighty', 'ninety'];

  if (num > 0 && num < 10) { // 1 to 9

    outNum = ones[num]; // ones

  } else if (num > 9 && num < 20) { // 10 to 19

    outNum = teens[(num % 10)]; // teens

  } else if (num > 19 && num < 100) { // 20 to 100

    outNum = tens[Math.floor(num / 10)]; // tens

    if (num % 10 > 0) {

      outNum = outNum + " " + ones[num % 10]; // tens + ones

    }

  }

  return outNum;

}

Update

The proposed solution shows the wrong result in some cases. More tests are needed.

Please try:

=GOOGLETRANSLATE(BAHTTEXT(7245.01),"th","en")

The result is

Seven thousand two hundred forty five baht, one satang

Then use regex or text function to get rid/replace this:

  • baht → to $ or currency
  • satang → to cents or other.

Here's the list of language codes for translation:

https://www.loc.gov/standards/iso639-2/php/code_list.php

I made a formula for Google Sheets that works with a range of cells or a single cell. The formula is

=LET(range, A2:A, 
ONE_TO_NINETEEN, {""; "One"; "Two"; "Three"; "Four"; "Five"; "Six"; "Seven"; "Eight"; "Nine"; "Ten"; "Eleven"; "Twelve"; "Thirteen"; "Fourteen"; "Fifteen"; "Sixteen"; "Seventeen"; "Eighteen"; "Nineteen"}, 
TWENTY_TO_NINETY, {""; "Twenty"; "Thirty"; "Forty"; "Fifty"; "Sixty"; "Seventy"; "Eighty"; "Ninety"}, 
PERIODS, {""; "Thousand"; "Million"; "Billion"; "Trillion"}, 

oneToNineteen, LAMBDA(i, INDEX(ONE_TO_NINETEEN, i + 1)), 
twentyToNinety, LAMBDA(i, INDEX(TWENTY_TO_NINETY, i)), 
period, LAMBDA(i, INDEX(PERIODS, i)), 

oneToNinetyNine, LAMBDA(n, IF(n < 20, oneToNineteen(n), TEXTJOIN("-", TRUE, twentyToNinety(INT(n / 10)), oneToNineteen(MOD(n, 10))))), 
hundreds, LAMBDA(n, IF(n < 100, "", oneToNineteen(INT(n / 100)) & " Hundred")), 

addPeriodWords, LAMBDA(dollars, words, i, LET(digits, INT(MOD(dollars / 1000^i, 1000)), IF(digits = 0, words, TEXTJOIN(" ", TRUE, hundreds(digits), oneToNinetyNine(MOD(digits, 100)), period(i + 1), words)))), 
makeDollarWords, LAMBDA(dollars, REDUCE("", SEQUENCE(1, ROWS(PERIODS), 0), LAMBDA(words, i, addPeriodWords(dollars, words, i)))), 

dollarsToWords, LAMBDA(dollars, IF(dollars = 0, "Zero", makeDollarWords(dollars))), 
centsToWords, LAMBDA(cents, SWITCH(cents, 0, "", 1, "and 1 Cent", JOIN(" ", "and", cents, "Cents"))), 
numberToWords, LAMBDA(n, LET(roundedCents, INT(ROUND(n - INT(n), 2) * 100), dollars, INT(n) + INT(roundedCents / 100), cents, MOD(roundedCents, 100), TEXTJOIN(" ", TRUE, dollarsToWords(dollars), centsToWords(cents)))), 

MAP(range, LAMBDA(n, IF(NOT(ISNUMBER(n)), , IF(OR(n < 0, n >= 10^15), "ERROR: Number should be greater or equal to zero and less than a Quadrillion", numberToWords(n))))))

In this Google Sheets spreadsheet, you can see the formula working under the column labeled " U.S. Dollars v3".

If you are using SRV-based connection strings (mongodb+srv://), no changes are required as DNS will resolve the new IPs automatically.

answers.body:
The --git is to mean that diff is in the "git" diff format. It doesn't refers to and option of the /usr/bin/diff command You can find the list of diff format documentation. Other formats are:

  • diff --combined
  • diff --cc
  • diff --summary

It's an "imaginary diff option", used to indicate to the reader that it's not just the output of running the diff command. For example, in git's own git repo:

$ git diff HEAD~1..HEAD | head
diff --git Documentation/git.txt Documentation/git.txt
index bd659c4..7913fc2 100644
--- Documentation/git.txt
+++ Documentation/git.txt
@@ -43,6 +43,11 @@ unreleased) version of Git, that is available from the 'master'
 branch of the `git.git` repository.
 Documentation for older releases are available here:
 
+* link:v2.10.0/git.html[documentation for release 2.10]
+
$

The diff command itself, if you invoked it with the same file name twice, would show no differences. git presumably creates temporary files corresponding to two different versions of Documentation/git.txt and feeds them to diff -- but the names of those temporary files would not be useful. I think git diff massages the output of diff to make it more meaningful to the reader. (This speculation was not entirely correct. See below.)

Diving into the git source code, diff.c has the string "diff --git" hardwired as a string literal:

strbuf_addf(&header, "%s%sdiff --git %s %s%s\n", line_prefix, meta, a_one, b_two, reset);

And looking into the history of diff.c for the earliest version that contains that string:

$ git log -n 1 b58f23b3
commit b58f23b38a9a9f28d751311353819d3cdf6a86da
Author: Junio C Hamano <junkio@cox.net>
Date:   2005-05-18 09:10:47 -0700

    [PATCH] Fix diff output take #4.
    
    This implements the output format suggested by Linus in
    <Pine.LNX.4.58.0505161556260.18337@ppc970.osdl.org>, except the
    imaginary diff option is spelled "diff --git" with double dashes as
    suggested by Matthias Urlichs.
    
    Signed-off-by: Junio C Hamano <junkio@cox.net>
    Signed-off-by: Linus Torvalds <torvalds@osdl.org>
$

Presumably <Pine.LNX...> is the message-id of some email message in a mailing list somewhere. In any case, this commit message makes it clear that diff --git is an "imaginary diff option".

This email message, cited by nos in a comment, appears to be part of the discussion that led to this. Update: That link is now dead, and I don't know whether the archive is available elsewhere.

UPDATE: I speculated above that git diff massages the output of diff, adding this information. I just tried running git diff under strace. It doesn't actually invoke the diff command, or any other command. Rather, all the output is printed by the git process itself, and apparently it computes the differences internally. This behavior might also depend on the version of git (I'm using 2.23.0), the diff command(s) available, and the arguments used.

I'll note that GNU diff has a --label=LABEL option that could be used for this kind of thing:

'-L LABEL'
'--label=LABEL'
     Use LABEL instead of the file name in the context format (*note
     Context Format::) and unified format (*note Unified Format::)
     headers.  *Note RCS::.

but git diff doesn't use it, at least in the one case I tried, and I don't see a reference to it in the git sources.

As Keith mentioned, in GNU diff (check your version with diff -v), you can have git-style patches by using --label like so:

a single file from a backup

diff -u --label a/path/to/file.ext --label b/path/to/file.ext path/to/file.ext~ path/to/file.ext

or from STDIN

command_that_outputs_previous_version | diff -u --label a/path/to/file.ext --label b/path/to/file.ext - path/to/file.ext

You can use those commands in a loop of files from find, etc. Where one side of a comparison does not exist, e.g. new files, compare with /dev/null.

items.title: What does the "diff --git" output in "git diff" refer to?
items.body:
When I run git diff, the output begins with:

diff --git a/foo/bar b/foo/bar

If I try to run plain old diff --git, I'm told that the --git option doesn't exist (obviously, I guess, it would seem silly for a low-level tool to know about a specific DVCS). There's no mention of it in the man page as well. Where does this come from?

import polars as pl

answers.body: That's correct. Data in the InfluxDB are saved in the UTC timezone, e.g. 2022-01-04 18:53:00 UTC. But Grafana (dashboard) is located in CET timezone, so UTC time is showed in the CET timezone - 2022-01-04 18:53:00 UTC = 2022-01-04 19:53:00 CET. That's a default Grafana behaviour. You can customize it in the Grafana dashboard time setting. So you may set UTC timezone for the dashboard, if your want to see date in the same timezone as you have saved in the InfluxDB.

answers.body:
Yes, you need to tell AutoMapper about each mapping. It will not guess for you. So, if an OrderDTO should map to an Order, you must tell AutoMapper that. You must also specify the reverse relationship if that's needed as well (i.e. Order should map to OrderDTO).

In other words, for bi-directional mapping you would need:

Mapper.CreateMap<Order, OrderDTO>();
Mapper.CreateMap<OrderDTO, Order>();

As far as Customer goes, if both Customer and CustomerDTO have a property named Orders, you don't need to do anything else. As long as you've told AutoMapper to map between Order and OrderDTO and Customer and CustomerDTO, it will automatically map your Order when you map Customer.

answers.body:
I have used RockDB state-store for checkpointing, this solved my issue. Following configs i have added to my sparksession.

      // Increase read/connection retries to overcome transient S3 I/O errors
      config("spark.hadoop.fs.s3a.retry.limit", "20"). // Default is 4
      config("spark.hadoop.fs.s3a.connection.retry.count", "20").
      config("spark.hadoop.fs.s3a.read.timeout", "60000"). // 60 seconds (default is 10000ms)
      //Configuration for Checkpoint tuning
      config("spark.sql.streaming.minBatchesToRetain", "500"). // Set higher than default(100) // Increase metadata logs kept for recovery from 100 to 200 or more
      config("spark.sql.streaming.stateStore.minDeltasForSnapshot", "10").
      // RocksDB state store configs
      config("spark.sql.streaming.stateStore.providerClass", "org.apache.spark.sql.execution.streaming.state.RocksDBStateStoreProvider").
      config("spark.sql.streaming.stateStore.rocksdb.blockCacheSize", "512m").
      config("spark.sql.streaming.stateStore.rocksdb.writeBufferSize", "64m").
      config("spark.sql.streaming.stateStore.rocksdb.compactionStyle", "universal").
      config("spark.sql.streaming.stateStore.rocksdb.numThreads", "4").

Note: Since spark > 3.2 versions, rocks db state store is bundled in spark itself, hence no need of any external jars. Just add above configs to work.

items.title: How to configure Nginx so that X.509 authentication implemented with Spring Security works correctly?
items.body:
I have a REST API server application that authenticates users exclusively via X.509 authentication implemented with Spring Security, using the Common Name (CN) from the client certificate directly as the username. The application works perfectly when accessed directly. However, how should I configure Nginx if I want to access it indirectly through Nginx?

All the approaches I've seen involve performing mutual TLS (mTLS) authentication in Nginx first and then passing the CN to the backend server—but that would require me to modify my application's authentication logic, which I'd prefer not to do.

Is there really no other way? I also can't use TCP-level stream forwarding, because this Nginx instance is already serving other web applications on port 443, and I don’t want to open an additional port.

Additionally, I'm using WebFlux.

answers.body:
This isn't possible without serious hacks. The cleanest solution would be to remove the async void methods and keep a collection of Tasks or whatnot.

async void methods do notify their synchronization context of operations starting and ending (via OperationStarted and OperationCompleted). Old-school (.NET Framework) ASP.NET used this to detect when async void WebForms event handlers completed so they knew when they could send the response. WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext does not override these methods, so they are not used in WinForms (the base class implementations are noops). Normally I would say you can define your own SynchronizationContext wrapping the WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext and providing an implementation of OperationStarted and OperationCompleted. However, this will not work for Windows Forms because there's large portions of that framework that specifically require a WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext and will just silently fail if it's any other form of SynchronizationContext. And WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext, naturally, is sealed.

So, you're left with a more serious hack: use a dynamic runtime hooking library (like Harmony) to intercept calls to SynchronizationContext.OperationStarted and SynchronizationContext.OperationCompleted, and use that to keep a count. That maybe might work. I've used Harmony, but never for anything that crazy; good luck!

Use TaskCompletionSource


  static void Main()
        {
            ApplicationConfiguration.Initialize();

            int completedOperations = 0;

           
            var allDoneTcs = new TaskCompletionSource<bool>(TaskCreationOptions.RunContinuationsAsynchronously);

            void OperationCompleted()
            {               
                if (Interlocked.Increment(ref completedOperations) == 2)
                {
                    allDoneTcs.TrySetResult(true);
                }
            }

            using var form = new Form();

            form.Load += async (s, e) =>
            {
                await Task.Delay(1000).ConfigureAwait(false);
                OperationCompleted();
            };

            form.Shown += async (s, e) =>
            {
                await Task.Delay(2000).ConfigureAwait(false);
                OperationCompleted();
            };
            
            Application.Run(form);

            
            if (completedOperations < 2)
            {
                allDoneTcs.Task.GetAwaiter().GetResult();
            }

            MessageBox.Show($"Completed operations: {completedOperations}");
        }

If you can afford to have form visible then use FormClosing and cancel until completed :

static void Main()
{
    ApplicationConfiguration.Initialize();

    int completedOperations = 0;
    var allDone = new TaskCompletionSource<bool>();

    void OperationCompleted()
    {
        completedOperations++;
        if (completedOperations == 2)
            allDone.TrySetResult(true);
    }

    using var form = new Form();

    form.Load += async (s, e) =>
    {
        await Task.Delay(1000);
        OperationCompleted();
    };

    form.Shown += async (s, e) =>
    {
        await Task.Delay(2000);
        OperationCompleted();
    };

    bool reallyClosing = false;

    // Don't let the form close until both async handlers have finished
    form.FormClosing += async (s, e) =>
    {
        if (reallyClosing)
            return; // second time, just let it close

        if (completedOperations < 2)
        {
            e.Cancel = true;          // keep Application.Run(form) alive
            await allDone.Task;       // wait until completedOperations == 2
            reallyClosing = true;
            form.Close();             // now close for real
        }
    };

    Application.Run(form);

    // Here both async operations are guaranteed completed and the form is closed
    MessageBox.Show($"Completed operations: {completedOperations}");
}

items.title: How to force the Application.Run to wait for all async void handlers?
items.body:
I have a Windows Forms application and a Form with many async void event handlers. This form can be closed by the user at any moment. After closing the form I want to delete a temporary file, and my problem is that the file might still be used by some async void event handler of my form, resulting in an IOException. The code that deletes the file is placed immediately after the Application.Run(form) call inside the Main method. My question is: how can I force the Application.Run method to keep blocking the Main execution flow, until all async void event handlers of my form are completed?

Here is a minimal demonstration of the desirable behavior:

[STAThread]
static void Main()
{
    ApplicationConfiguration.Initialize();
    int completedOperations = 0;
    Form form = new();
    form.Load += async (s, e) =>
    {
        await Task.Delay(1000);
        completedOperations++;
    };
    form.Shown += async (s, e) =>
    {
        await Task.Delay(2000);
        completedOperations++;
    };
    Application.Run(form);
    MessageBox.Show($"Completed operations: {completedOperations}");
}

The desirable output is:

Completed operations: 2

Both async void operations should always be completed when the execution flow reaches the final MessageBox.Show line. The actual (undesirable) output of the above code depends on how quickly the user will close the window. If she closes it in less than two seconds, only 0 or 1 operations might be completed.

Clarification: Configuring the Task.Delay(1000) with .ConfigureAwait(false) is not an option. My actual event handlers interact with UI components, so it's mandatory to resume on the UI thread after the await.

answers.body:
I stumbled upon your challange and it sparked my interest.

Although I don't fully understand how you want the user to select a date range through a month slicer, I have created a report as follows:
enter image description here
The report user can select a date range, and the table will show all employees who worked an average of 48 hours per week (or more) in any 4 month window within the select date range.
The period(s) when this happened are shown and concatenated (since there can be multiple periods within the selected range that meet the criteria).
Only full months are taken into account.

To accomplish this, I have created 2 measures.
The first measure calculates the weekly average for any date for the following 4 months to come.
The countrows() / 7 part calculates the number of weeks, because not every 4 month period is exactly 16 weeks long.
You can change this to a hard 16 if you want.

Rolling4MonthWeeklyAverage = 
DIVIDE(
    CALCULATE(
        SUM(table[WorkHours]),
        DATESINPERIOD( table[Date], MAX(table[Date]), 4, MONTH ),
        ALL(table)
    ),
    COUNTROWS(
        DATESINPERIOD( table[Date], MAX(table[Date]), 4, MONTH )) / 7,
    BLANK()
)

The second measure generates a list of dates, all 1ste of the month dates in the date range that is selected.
It adds a column for the month range (I have added the year, in case multiple years are selected).
After, it adds a column with the weekly average over these 4 months.
It returns a concatenated string with all periods together.
Please note that it doesn't take into account periods like 15 April - 14 Augustus, since your request didn't specify on these possibilities.
The measure is as follows:

Overworked = 
var minDate = MIN(table[Date])
var maxDate = MAX(table[Date])
var series = 
    FILTER(
        DATESBETWEEN(table[Date],minDate,EDATE(maxDate,-4)),
        DAY(table[Date])=1
    )
var periodTable = 
    ADDCOLUMNS(
        series,
        "Period",
        FORMAT([Date],"MMM-YY")&" till "&FORMAT(EDATE([Date],4),"MMM-YY"),
        "Avg",
        VALUE(FORMAT([Rolling4MonthWeeklyAverage],"#.0"))
    )
RETURN
CONCATENATEX(
    FILTER(periodTable,[Avg]>48),
    [Period]&": "&[Avg],
    " "&UNICHAR(10),
    [Avg],
    DESC
)

I hope this will help you at least a bit.
Let me know if you have follow up questions.

Please forgive any spelling errors, English is not my native language.

master flow:

Create data table --> Calculate total work hours --> rolling --> 4 month average --> exceed 48 hours condition --> Generate overlap 4-month windows.

Create data table

DateTable = 
ADDCOLUMNS(
    CALENDAR(DATE(2020,1,1), DATE(2025,12,31)),
    "Year", YEAR([Date]),
    "Month", FORMAT([Date], "YYYY-MM"),
    "MonthName", FORMAT([Date], "MMM")
)

calculate total work hours

TotalWorkHours = SUM('Attendance'[WorkHours])

rolling

Rolling4MonthWorkHours = 
CALCULATE(
    SUM('Attendance'[WorkHours]),
    DATESINPERIOD(
        'DateTable'[Date], 
        LASTDATE('DateTable'[Date]), 
        -4, 
        MONTH
    )
)

4 month average

4MonthAverageHoursPerWeek = 
DIVIDE(
    [Rolling4MonthWorkHours], 
    16
)

exceed 48 hours condition

Exceeds48HoursCondition = 
IF([4MonthAverageHoursPerWeek] > 48, 1, 0)

Generate overlap 4-month windows

Rolling4MonthWindows = 
VAR SelectedStartMonth = MIN('DateTable'[Date])
VAR SelectedEndMonth = MAX('DateTable'[Date])
RETURN
    GENERATE(
        DATESINPERIOD('DateTable'[Date], SelectedStartMonth, 4, MONTH),
        VAR StartDate = MIN('DateTable'[Date])
        VAR EndDate = EDATE(StartDate, 3)  -- Adds 3 months to start to create 4-month window
        RETURN
            ROW(
                "Window", FORMAT(StartDate, "MMM") & "–" & FORMAT(EndDate, "MMM"),
                "StartDate", StartDate,
                "EndDate", EndDate
            )
    )

items.title: How to calculate overlapping 4-month rolling averages with a month slicer?
items.body:
I have an attendance summary table with the following columns:

  • EmployeeID

  • Date

  • WorkHours

I need to create a visual (or table widget) in Power BI that shows employees who worked more than 48 hours on average per week across any 4-month window.

Here’s the logic I want:

  • The user selects a date range using a month slicer.

  • The model should dynamically calculate all possible 4-month rolling windows within the selected range.

  • For each 4-month window, if an employee’s total work hours across those months divided by 16 (weeks) is greater than 48, that record should appear in the table.

  • Each result should also show the month range (for example: “Jan–Apr”, “Feb–May”, etc.) where the condition was met.

Example:
If the user selects months from January to August, the calculation should evaluate:

  • Jan–Apr

  • Feb–May

  • Mar–Jun

  • Apr–Jul

  • May–Aug

And list all employees exceeding the 48-hour average condition in any of those windows.

I’ve tried a few DAX approaches using DATESINPERIOD, GENERATE, and CALCULATETABLE, but I’m struggling to dynamically generate these 4-month windows and compute the rolling condition correctly.

answers.body:
I'd say "a little bit" and "it depends" - three function calls will be compiled as three function calls and not one, due to preserving any side effects. But mostly any difference will be minor.

Code formatting itself won't matter, if a formatter will have the same output for all inputs, the compiled code will also be the same. Length of names also don't matter, they're reduced internally to addresses and tokens. But intermediate variables (used only once, added for clarity) usually are eliminated, but that depends on the compiler, so falls under "a little bit" and "it depends" again.
more like if/else vs switch or implicit vs explicit typing

items.title: Does the way a program is written/formatted affect how fast and large it is at compile time?
items.body:
We all know that there's no wrong way to write code, and infinite possible ways to complete a task. Everyone codes differently.

There are of course many ways to shorthand code, so the same code can be done in much fewer characters, and we can (usually) put in as much whitespace as we like.

The following Swift program:

for x in 1...100 {
    print( "The number is:\n" + String(x) + "\n" )
}

...can also be written like this:

var x = 1
while x <= 100 {
    print("The number is:")
    print(x)
    print("")

    x = x+1
}

...or even this:

for x in 1...100 {print("The number is:\n\(x)\n")}

...all with the exact same result.

Of course, each file is going to be a different size due to the way each script is written. But what about once it is compiled at runtime? Does the way a program is written affect how it runs?

answers.body: I recommend doing the repo fetching with a toplevel west.yml manifest and including your lib with add_library() or the appropriate cmake function.

I was also having an issue trying to link my own library to the Zephyr application -- getting the "Conflicting CPU architectures" error message at link time.

I was able to resolve this and successfully link my library by linking my library to the zephyr_interface library. For example:

add_library(my-lib STATIC ${MY_SRCS})
target_link_libraries(my-lib PUBLIC zephyr_interface)
target_link_libraries(app PRIVATE my-lib)

According to the Zephyr CMakeLists.txt linking to this library sets compiler flags to match the Zephyr build:

# "zephyr_interface" is a source-less library that encapsulates all the global
# compiler options needed by all source files. All zephyr libraries,
# including the library named "zephyr" link with this library to
# obtain these flags.
# https://cmake.org/cmake/help/latest/manual/cmake-buildsystem.7.html#interface-libraries
add_library(zephyr_interface INTERFACE)

I found previous answers to be unhelpful.

If you have this folder structure with a sandpit app. And a shared library folder outside of it like this (this is how I like to organise my files)...


        nrf/
        ├── x-sand-pit/
        │   └── custom-brd-sandpit/
        │       └── blinky/
        │           ├── CMakeLists.txt
        │           └── src/
        │               └── main.c
        │
        └── monkey-libs/
            ├── monkey_core/
            │   ├── CMakeLists.txt
            │   ├── include/
            │   │   └── monkey_core.h
            │   └── src/
            │       └── monkey_core.c
            │
            └── monkey_template/
                ├── CMakeLists.txt
                ├── include/
                │   └── monkey_template.h
                └── src/
                    └── monkey_template.c

Your CMakeLists.txt (in Blinky app) could look like this:


cmake_minimum_required(VERSION 3.20.0)
find_package(Zephyr REQUIRED HINTS $ENV{ZEPHYR_BASE})
project(
    blinky
    VERSION 1.0
    DESCRIPTION "Using Custom board files with LED overlays"
    LANGUAGES C
)

# App
target_sources(app PRIVATE src/main.c)

# Set Important Paths
set(MONKEY_LIB_DIR     ../../../monkey-libs)

# Include the library (via directory)
add_subdirectory(
    ${MONKEY_LIB_DIR}/monkey_template 
    ${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/monkey/monkey_template
)

add_subdirectory(
    ${MONKEY_LIB_DIR}/monkey_core 
    ${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}/monkey/monkey_core
)

# Link the library to the application
target_link_libraries(app PRIVATE monkey_template)
target_link_libraries(app PRIVATE monkey_core)

And your library cmake file could be like this:

zephyr_library_named(monkey_template)

# # Explicit list
zephyr_library_sources(
    src/monkey_template.c
)

# Put the single public level .h file in includes folder
zephyr_include_directories(
    include
)

# Access to other Monkey libs (Strict rules to avoid circular dependency)
target_link_libraries(monkey_template PRIVATE monkey_core)

This shows how to add an external library into your main application, and also how to include one library into another - with a note to be careful not to do anything stupid!

answers.body:
When NoDriver (and similar tools like Playwright, Puppeteer, or Pyppeteer) launches Chrome, it:

  1. Starts Chrome with --remote-debugging-port=XXXX.

  2. Immediately tries to connect to http://localhost:XXXX/json/version to get the browser version and WebSocket endpoint.

The problem is that macOS Chrome takes extra time to open its remote debugging port — especially on:

  • The first launch after being dormant.

  • When using a real user profile (which locks files and triggers macOS sandbox dialogs).

  • When launching Chrome headfully, not headless (extra UI overhead).

  • When gatekeeper or background Chrome processes delay port binding.

So the HTTP ConnectionRefusedError happens simply because the port isn’t ready yet — the Chrome process exists but hasn’t yet started listening on the debugging port.

Your observation that it succeeds if you open and quit Chrome first is the biggest clue: the launch warms caches, profile DBs, and permissions, shortening startup time.

1. If using a real Chrome profile, copy it or use Chromium

Chrome often locks its profile (singleton lock) so NoDriver can’t attach.
Chromium doesn’t enforce this lock as strictly — which explains why it works there.

If you must use the real profile:

  • Don’t open Chrome manually while running NoDriver.

  • Copy the profile folder somewhere else before starting:

    import shutil, os, tempfile

original = "/Users/you/Library/Application Support/Google/Chrome/Profile 1"
temp = tempfile.mkdtemp()
shutil.copytree(original, os.path.join(temp, "Profile 1"))
browser = await start(
    headless=False,
    args=[f"--user-data-dir={temp}", "--profile-directory=Profile 1"],
)

2. Check for zombie processes

macOS sometimes leaves behind Google Chrome Helper (Renderer) background daemons even after Chrome quits.
You can clear them with:

pkill -9 "Google Chrome"
pkill -9 "Chromium"

before launching your automation script

This happens because Chrome sometimes isn’t ready to accept DevTools connections when NoDriver tries to fetch its version right after startup.
Chrome’s remote debugging socket takes a short moment to come online. On a cold start (especially after macOS sleeps or when the browser hasn’t run in a while), the port may not yet be listening, causing [Errno 61] Connection refused.
The crash is misleading, i think it’s a timing issue.
Keep in mind that Chromium works better because it usually initializes faster and doesn’t lock profiles the same way Chrome does.

from nodriver import *
import asyncio, os

async def start_browser():
    browser_path = "/Applications/Google Chrome.app/Contents/MacOS/Google Chrome"
    user_data = os.path.expanduser("~/Library/Application Support/NoDriverProfile")

    browser = await start(
        headless=False,
        browser_executable_path=browser_path,
        user_data_dir=user_data,
        no_sandbox=True,
        start_timeout=10,        # here is a custom arg supported in recent versions
    )

    await asyncio.sleep(2)       #a wait extra before connecting
    tab = await browser.get("https://example.com")
    return tab

asyncio.run(start_browser())

If you still get intermittent failures, clear leftover Chrome processes and cached sockets before launching:

pkill -f "Google Chrome"
rm -rf ~/Library/Application\ Support/NoDriverProfile/Singleton*

In conclusion, Chrome sometimes takes longer to expose its debugging port: consider using a dedicated user_data_dir, add a small startup delay, and avoid --profile-directory which causes early connection refusals on macOS.

You can check Chrome DevTools Protocol for background on how NoDriver connects.

This error happens because Chrome’s remote debugging endpoint isn’t ready yet when NoDriver tries to read the browser version. The connection fails during startup:

aiohttp.client_exceptions.ClientConnectorError: Cannot connect to host localhost:<port> [Connect call failed ('127.0.0.1', <port>)]

On macOS, this is common because Chrome can take a bit longer to open its DevTools socket, especially when using an existing profile.

Please following:

1. Use a dedicated user_data_dir (avoid profile locking)

Don’t use your default Chrome profile or --profile-directory. Instead, create a separate directory for NoDriver, for example:

user_data = os.path.expanduser("~/Library/Application Support/NoDriverProfile")

macOS will refuse the DevTools connection if another Chrome process locks the default profile.

2. Increase NoDriver’s startup timeout

Give Chrome more time to open the debugging port:

browser = await start(
    headless=False,
    browser_executable_path=browser_path,
    user_data_dir=user_data,
    no_sandbox=True,
    start_timeout=10,   # important
)

3. Add a short delay before calling browser.get()

Even after launch succeeds, Chrome may still be preparing the DevTools socket:

await asyncio.sleep(2)
tab = await browser.get("https://example.com")

This prevents ConnectionRefusedError when calling browser.get.

4. Clean up leftover Chrome processes & profile lock files

Before running the script, kill any orphaned Chrome processes and delete “Singleton” files that lock a profile:

pkill -f "Google Chrome"
rm -rf ~/Library/Application\ Support/NoDriverProfile/Singleton*

These files frequently cause the DevTools endpoint to reject connections.

Working example

import asyncio, os
from nodriver import start

async def start_browser():
    browser_path = "/Applications/Google Chrome.app/Contents/MacOS/Google Chrome"
    user_data = os.path.expanduser("~/Library/Application Support/NoDriverProfile")

    browser = await start(
        headless=False,
        browser_executable_path=browser_path,
        user_data_dir=user_data,
        no_sandbox=True,
        start_timeout=10,
    )

    await asyncio.sleep(2)   # Give the debugging port time to open

    tab = await browser.get("https://example.com")
    return tab

asyncio.run(start_browser())

Set this to the name of a color asset in your asset catalog, e.g.

The system will only apply this color where it should be applied.

answers.body:
To uppercase what's in between commas, you could use:

(my $x = 'a,b,c,d,e') =~ s/(?<=,)([^,]*)(?=,)/ uc($1) /eg;   # a,B,C,D,e

                  a,b,c,d,e
Pass 1 matches      -
Pass 2 matches        -
Pass 3 matches          -

If you didn't use lookarounds, this is what you'd get,

(my $x = 'a,b,c,d,e') =~ s/,([^,]*),/ ','.uc($1).',' /eg;   # a,B,c,D,e

                  a,b,c,d,e
Pass 1 matches     ---
Pass 2 matches         ---

Not only does the lookahead avoid repetition, it doesn't work without it!

Another somewhat common use is as part of a string equivalent to [^CHAR].

foo(?:(?!foo|bar).)*bar  # foo..bar, with no nested foo or bar

You can use it to narrow down character classes.

\w(?<!\d)     # A word char that's not a digit.

Although this can now be done using (?[ ... ]).

It's also useful in more esoteric patterns.

 /a/ && /b/ && /c/

can be written as

 /^(?=.*?a)(?=.*?b).*?c/s

lookahead lets you check for a pattern without actually matching it.

When you do a(?=b) ,you would match a if its followed by b. Note:it doesn't match b.

So,

  1. You can extract hello(without #) from #hello# using

    (?<=#)hello(?=#)

  2. You can validate passwords with requirements such as a password must have 2 digits,2 letters or more with any other character

    ^(?=(.\d){2})(?=(.[a-z]){2}).*$

Try doing above without lookahead ,you would realize it's importance

I have found lookaheads especially useful for checking multiple conditions. For example, consider a regex that checks that a password has at least one lowercase, one uppercase, one numeric, and one symbol character, and is at least 8 characters in length:

^(?=.*[a-z])(?=.*[A-Z])(?=.*[0-9])(?=.*[^a-zA-Z0-9]).{8,}$

Try to devise a regex to do the same thing without lookahead assertions! It's possible, but it's extremely cumbersome.

Meanwhile, I've found lookbehinds especially useful for checking boundary conditions—that is, for example, matching a string of 0's, unless it's preceded by another number, like 1000067.

These are my experiences but certainly there are many more practical uses and the way everyone uses a tool can vary from person to person.

There are many reasons to use lookarounds, e.g.

  1. limiting the substring that is considered to be matched: s/(?<=[0-9])+(?=[0-9])/-/ instead of s/([0-9])+([0-9])/$1-$2/.
  2. and-ing various conditions together: /(?=\p{Uppercase}\p{Lowercase})\p{InBasicLatin}{2,}/.

Lookaround assertions is useful when you need a pattern to help locate the match but you don't want the pattern to be part of what is captured.

Here's a simple scenario with lookahead assertion:

Let's say I have

my $text = '98 degrees, 99 Red Balloons, 101 Dalmatians'

and I want to change the number of red balloons from its previous value to 9001, so I use

$text =~ s/\d+(?=Red Balloons)/9001/;

Lookaround assertions are like any other assertion: you want to make a condition that doesn't consume any part of the string.

We have an example in Learning Perl where we ask reader to match a string that contains Fred and Wilma, in any order. At that level, the trick we intend is that people decide to use two patterns instead of one, which is often easier to read:

if( /Fred/ && /Wilma/ ) { ... }

Some people, given only the features we had presented so far, do come up with a single pattern:

if( /Fred.*Wilma|Wilma.*Fred/ ) { ... }

That's not as satisfying because it repeats two strings (so two more spots to make a typo or forget to update), and it's a bit harder to read (and we hadn't shown /x yet).

In Mastering Perl, I revisit this example and use a positive lookahead assertion (the (?=...)) to get a shorter form of the single regex that doesn't repeat itself:

if( /(?=.*Fred)Wilma/ ) { ... }

Except in very tight, hot loop situations, I'd probably stick with the two regex approach to be kind to the maintainers. Not many people can look at lookarounds and

Negative lookarounds

But, I think it's easier to understand negative lookarounds first, and find they are much more useful. What if we wanted to match a string that has Wilma, but not Fred? That's easy as two patterns:

if( /Wilma/ && ! /Fred/ ) { ... }

The negative case is like the positive case, with (?!=...) with the extra !:

if( /(?!=.*Fred)Wilma/ ) { ... }

Many positive lookarounds are often able to be rewritten without the lookaround because their text must appear in the string. The negative lookarounds aren't so fortunate since their text cannot appear in the string. We have easier ways to make character classes that assert that a single character in set of characters cannot be in a certain position, but no good way to say a substring cannot appear (but there are some tricks with FAIL that we don't need to get into).

I had one task that was going through a list of part numbers for something, and their strings looked something like this, where the ABC prefix meant something, the EF substring meant something, and then there's a number:

ABC-EF1234

I forget almost everything about this problem, but there were certain combinations of the first alphabetic group along with things they did not want for the second. The tricky thing here is that we know the positions of the strings, so it's not as easy as matching anywhere in the string.

Excluding the ones we don't want are easier than doing a lot of extra work, especially when everything else around this code is geared toward a single pattern:

    /^ (ABC | GRT | JKL)
        - 
       (?!= XY | ZZ | ER ) ([A-Z]{2})
       [0-9]{4}
    \z
    /x;

This worked out nicely because there was an additional concern. My only affordance was the pattern. Previously they only selected on simple things, like a set of known prefixes or certain numbers, so the code was built around that:

foreach my $part ( part_numbers($pattern) ) {...}

In these sorts of cases, where the foreach expects that whatever is in $part is ready to use and needs no more filtering. Sure, anyone could completely rewrite this code and give it lots of dials and knobs, but the code would be harder to read, possibly introduce bugs, and all the other traps of rewriting code to be more general. Instead, use some pattern magic and leave the code as it is.

How else might you do this? You could break apart the string, which works until you have the weird part number that everyone hates to see in their Excel spreadsheets because it messes up everything because someone in logistics fat-fingered something years ago, it got into a cataloge, and everyone knows this special case. Anyway:

my( $prefix, $middle, $number ) = /\A([A-Z]{3}) - ([A-Z]){2} ([0-9]{4}) \z/x;
if( $prefix =~ /.../ and $middle !~ /.../ ) { ... }

This works for just that case, but what about the case where we don't care what the middle is? The you end up with a lot of branching to try different conditions. With the negative lookahead, that was just part of the pattern and not the logic of the code.

items.title: React Three.js: "Error creating WebGL context" even though WebGL works on https://get.webgl.org/
items.body:
I'm developing a hero section for my React portfolio that includes a 3D model rendered with Three.js via @react-three/fiber. However, when the component loads, I see this error in the browser console:

ErrorBoundary caught an error: Error creating WebGL context.

To verify if this was a browser or GPU issue, I tested WebGL support on https://get.webgl.org/ — and it worked fine. So, WebGL is supported and functional, but my Three.js scene still fails to initialize.

Link to test in web: https://stackblitz.com/edit/vitejs-vite-hdwgdgwy?file=src%2FApp.jsx

Why would WebGL work on the test site but fail to initialize in a React/Three.js app? What are common causes of the "Error creating WebGL context" error in a React setup using @react-three/fiber?

Steps to Reproduce:

  1. Create the following React component:
// ComputersCanvas.jsx
import { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import { Canvas } from "@react-three/fiber";
import { OrbitControls, Preload, useGLTF } from "@react-three/drei";

const Computers = ({ isMobile }) => {
  const { scene } = useGLTF("./desktop_pc/scene.gltf");

  return (
    <mesh>
      <hemisphereLight intensity={0.15} groundColor="black" />
      <primitive
        object={scene}
        scale={isMobile? 0.7: 0.75}
        position={isMobile ? [0, -3, -2.2] : [0, -3.25, -1.5]}
        rotation={[-0.01, -0.2, -0.1]}
      />
    </mesh>
  );
};

const ComputersCanvas = () => {
  const [isMobile, setIsMobile] = useState(false);

  useEffect(() => {
    const mediaQuery = window.matchMedia("(max-width: 500px)");
    setIsMobile(mediaQuery.matches);
    const handleMediaQueryChange = (event) => setIsMobile(event.matches);
    mediaQuery.addEventListener("change", handleMediaQueryChange);
    return () => mediaQuery.removeEventListener("change", handleMediaQueryChange);
  }, []);

  return (
    <Canvas
      frameloop="demand"
      dpr={[1, 1.5]}
      camera={{ position: [20, 3, 5], fov: 25 }}
      gl={{ preserveDrawingBuffer: true }}
    >
      <OrbitControls
        enableZoom={false}
        maxPolarAngle={Math.PI / 2}
        minPolarAngle={Math.PI / 2}
      />
      <Computers isMobile={isMobile} />
      <Preload all />
    </Canvas>
  );
};

export default ComputersCanvas;
  1. Render it in your App.jsx:
import React from "react";
import ComputersCanvas from "./components/ComputersCanvas";

function App() {
  return (
    <div style={{ width: "100vw", height: "100vh", background: "#0a0a0a" }}>
      <h1 style={{ color: "#fff", textAlign: "center", paddingTop: "20px" }}>
        3D Portfolio Demo
      </h1>
      <div style={{ width: "100%", height: "90vh" }}>
        <ComputersCanvas />
      </div>
    </div>
  );
}

export default App;
  1. Install dependencies:
npm install three @react-three/fiber @react-three/drei

What I tried:

  • Verified WebGL support at https://get.webgl.org/ – works fine.
  • Confirmed model path /public/desktop_pc/scene.gltf exists.
  • Tried removing frameloop='demand' and preserveDrawingBuffer, same issue.
  • The error occurs before the scene even loads.

Environment

  • OS: Windows 10
  • Browser: Chrome 141
  • React: 18.3.1
  • @react-three/drei: 9.105.0
  • three: 0.168.0

Additional Info

  • get.webgl.org confirms WebGL runs fine in this environment.
  • The error happens immediately after rendering .
  • No network errors are logged — the .gltf model file exists in /public/desktop_pc/scene.gltf.

answers.body:
It would most likely not be faster and it could even be incorrect.

(1) likely not faster:

Latency Numbers every programmer should know has a random read on an SSD as a hundred thousand times slower than a typical instruction. So your problem is totally dominated by disk, the tiny amount of compute that your approach may save is irrelevant.

(2) likely not correct:

If you sum a billion integers as integers, you will likely run into the problem of integer overflow. Your result will be nonsense if that happens. Might also be that some part of your stack notices this happening and throws an error instead. Failure either way. Casting the input numbers to Double avoids this problem, because double-precision floating-point-numbers have enormous range.

old

SELECT 
    SUM(CAST(int_field AS DOUBLE)), COUNT(int_field)
FROM
    fact

new

SELECT 
    CAST(SUM(int_field) AS DOUBLE), COUNT(int_field)
FROM
    fact

In this case the error is because you have not installed impacket for python2.7.

  • Before installing impacket we need to install pip2 in python2.7, Download get-pip.py form Link

  • if pip2 is already installed you can verify this by pip --verison, output of that command should be pip 20.3.3 from /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pip (python 2.7)

  • If pip2 is not installed then install pip2 in python2 package using sudo python2 get-pip.py

  • Next, install impacket for python2 using pip install . (this must be with in the impacket directory link)

  • then try to run your script

answers.body:
It seems you are mixing PHP-FPM and a standalone PHP server. Rather move the artisan serve to the CMD. Also, you can only have one CMD, which is the command that needs to execute when the container starts. In order to execute other commands when building the container, you need to use the RUN command. So your Dockerfile can look like this:

WORKDIR '/app'
RUN curl -sS https://getcomposer.org/installer | \
            php -- --install-dir=/usr/bin/ --filename=composer

RUN "composer install"
EXPOSE 80
EXPOSE 22
CMD "php artisan serve --host 0.0.0.0 --port 80"

I'd like to help, but I'm not quite sure I understand your question. Given the information you have here, that code should work. The only unknown is the actual datatype of the value of the combo, but unless the .Field(Of T) is throwing an InvalidCastException, you should be good there. I wrote the following code and threw it into a unit test project, and everything came out good . . . at least with regard to the length of the resulting set of data.

Code

<TestCase(0, ExpectedResult:=4)>
    <TestCase(1, ExpectedResult:=4)>
    <TestCase(2, ExpectedResult:=3)>
    <TestCase(3, ExpectedResult:=2)>
    <TestCase(4, ExpectedResult:=1)>
    <TestCase(5, ExpectedResult:=0)>
    Public Function tmptest(ByVal selected As Integer) As Integer

        Dim d As New DataTable
        d.Columns.Add(New DataColumn("id", GetType(Integer)))
        For j = 0 To 5
            Dim r = d.NewRow()
            r("id") = j
            d.Rows.Add(r)
        Next

        If selected = 0 Then selected = 1
        Dim query = From status In d.AsEnumerable()
                    Where status.Field(Of Integer)("id") > selected
                    Select status


        Return query.Count
    End Function

Results

items.title: VB.NET: LINQ Query on DataTable - WHERE Id >=0
items.body:
Hey people,

I am bugfixing an application for some friends of mine. They are using VB.NET and Windows Forms, while I am in team C#/WPF/ASP. My knowledge about LINQ is also very limited even if its all .NET. I hope you can help me.

The situation
There are two combos on the form. They are getting their data from the same table status.
The order of the status objects depends on the id-column.
The second combo shall only contain status having id >= combo1.id. So that the user can only select status in the second combo that are "greater-equal" than the status in the first combo.
The smallest status.id is 3.

The code
(please ignore the useless back and forward casting of index etc. I wanted to show you the code as I revieved it.)

                    Dim index As String = cmbStatusFrom.SelectedValue.ToString()
                    If index = "0" Then
                        index = "1"
                    End If

                    Dim query As IEnumerable(Of DataRow) = _
                        From status In ContextDataTable.AsEnumerable() _
                        Where status.Field(Of Integer)("Id") >= Integer.Parse(index) _
                        Select status

The problem
Without 

If index = "0" Then  
    index = "1"  
End If

the resulting datatable contains one more row than it should. (0 means that the empty-item has been selected in the first combo) The row has id = 0 (like the empty-row)

Again, the smallest existing id is 3. So it should not make any difference if one uses >=0, 1, 2 or 3. But it seemingly does. Or more likely, there is some really stupid mistake in the code and which I just can't find.

Anyone has got an idea what the problem is?

I do appreciate any help. :-)

greetz steven
